title: Foppe de Haan
text:
Foppe Geert de Haan (, born 26 June 1943) is a Dutch <a href="association%20football">football</a> coach. He is known for his long association with <a href="Friesland">Frisian</a> club <a href="SC%20Heerenveen">SC Heerenveen</a>. De Haan was the manager of the <a href="Tuvalu%20national%20football%20team">Tuvalu national football team</a> during 2011 and then rejoined Heerenveen's youth programme. He is also a politician for the <a href="Partij%20van%20de%20Arbeid">Partij van de Arbeid</a>.
Career.
De Haan was born in <a href="Opsterland">Lippenhuizen</a>, <a href="Friesland">Friesland</a>. He started his managerial career in 1974 with VV Akkrum. After two years he combined this role with the youth team manager's position at <a href="SC%20Heerenveen">SC Heerenveen</a>. By 1978 he had become the manager for <a href="Drachtster%20Boys">Drachtster Boys</a>. He then moved to <a href="Asser%20Christelijke%20Voetbalvereniging">ACV</a> in 1980, and to <a href="Steenwijk">Steenwijk</a> in 1983. In 1985 de Haan re-joined Heerenveen, this time as assistant coach. He would go on to spend 20 years with the club, the longest time a coach worked for a Dutch professional football club. De Haan was made head coach in 1992, and in 1993 led the club back to the <a href="Eredivisie">Eredivisie</a>. The finished in second place in the Eredivisie with Heerenveen in 2000, thus qualifying for the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> for the first time in the club's history.
In 2003, he received the Sport Award and on 10 May 2004, after his final game as coach of SC Heerenveen, he was invested as a Knight of the <a href="Order%20of%20Orange-Nassau">Order of Orange-Nassau</a>. He was successively appointed as coach of the <a href="Netherlands%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Netherlands national under-21 football team</a> (), with whom he won the <a href="2006%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Football%20Championship">2006 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship</a> and <a href="2007%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Football%20Championship">2007 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship</a>. De Haan was accused by <a href="Steven%20Taylor%20%28footballer%29">Steven Taylor</a> of calling him a "cheat" as he had been injured in the match and was originally not going to take a penalty in the semi-final penalty shoot-out. Taylor eventually took and scored his penalty in the shootout which the <a href="Netherlands%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Netherlands</a> won despite this. A semifinal spot in the latter tournament also qualified the Dutch for the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics%26amp%3Bnbsp%3B%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament">2008 Summer Olympics football tournament</a>, leading his side to the quarter-finals where they were ultimately defeated by <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">Argentina</a> after <a href="extra%20time">extra time</a>.
De Haan had announced that he would retire from football at the end of the 2008–09 season, when his contract with the <a href="Royal%20Dutch%20Football%20Association">KNVB</a> expired. Instead he returned to work as a senior advisor at SC Heerenveen, before being appointed head coach at <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>n <a href="Premier%20Soccer%20League">Premier Soccer League</a> club <a href="Ajax%20Cape%20Town">Ajax Cape Town</a>.
De Haan managed the <a href="Tuvalu%20national%20football%20team">Tuvalu national football team</a> through their <a href="Men%27s%20football%20at%20the%202011%20Pacific%20Games">2011 Pacific Games</a> campaign. De Haan left his post after the tournament to rejoin Heerenveen's youth programme.
On 20 October 2015, De Haan became interim coach of SC Heerenveen after the team had a disappointing start of the season and <a href="Dwight%20Lodeweges">Dwight Lodeweges</a> left as head coach. Under De Haan the team went on to win 4 of their first six games, drawing and losing one.
Honours.
Netherlands
